text: [Music]
[Music]
Phil thank you so much for joining us
today at digital edge it's a pleasure
having you here to start off with I'd
love to ask you how do you kickstart an
enterprise to innovate an experiment
like a startup well if you look at the
difference between enterprises and
startups they both typically start with
a big vision which is great but the the
startup will then figure out how to
execute small they have finite resources
whereas enterprises they typically match
that big vision with big execution and
they want to spin up large projects and
commit a lot of resources which makes
failure a much bigger impact where
startups if something is not working
their hypothesis does not work out
they're just cut bait and so with
enterprises the key is to build
capabilities that allow you to not have
a lot of collateral damage from failed
experiments and so we're focusing on
those capabilities I used to give out a
failure bonus to teams where I cancelled
their project and that was to one
encourage them to want to experiment
more but I also didn't pay it out until
they had actually written a learning
document on what the organization could
take away from this a small investment
we had made but when it comes to AI and
machine learning where are you saying
tangible business outcomes
yeah well it's actually one of the top
two things that our AWS customers want
to figure out how to build into their
own business strategy and you think
about the most common ways that it's
being adapted today it's in the
prediction of customer preferences or
the delivery of personalized experiences
and what happens after that is actually
the the acceleration or optic Wicker
optimization of the new products and
services that are being delivered
through the analysis continuous analysis
of the data that's being generated
but and then but the the challenge for
most companies is that it's not like
building a regular customer application
or enterprise application it requires
data scientists typically and lots of
new skill sets that the organization
typically hasn't employed and one of the
things that we're focused on is how do
we make it more accessible to more
enterprises to actually embed these
predictive personalization capabilities
and that's why we offer services that to
provide the data scientists deep level
of learning and experimentation but also
things that everyday software engineers
can use to build in that personalization
and better customer experience yeah more
human experience absolutely so when it
comes to culture you know how would you
recommend that enterprises invest in
culture yeah you know what's really
interesting about culture is that many
people would argue that in their
company's culture is their most valuable
asset but ironically it's the one thing
you can't that money cannot buy and if
you look at the the cultures that many
consider to be thriving and growing they
they have two characteristics and one is
that they're adaptable and the second is
that they have this innate focus on
something whether it's a purpose or
customer and that's actually how Amazon
is organized around this customer
obsession and everything we do in our
organization is focused on customer
value with what and so the way we invest
in our culture is to develop mechanisms
and processes that actually reinforce
that whether it's working or working
backwards from the from the customer
where every new idea has to start with a
press release from the customers
perspective or our leadership principles
that we used to hire promote and make
decisions about new ideas right can you
talk to me more about the press release
for the customer yeah you mean by that
well it's a it's a it's the the press
release we call it the PR FAQ because
there's also a frequently asked
questions associated with it but the
press release is simply a one-page
document at its core that is the written
as if a proud new product was being
announced and it's written without
technical jargon or inside acronyms that
are expected to be understood by a
customer reading it and that's how we
start and socialize ideas and the thing
I really value about it is that whether
you're the CEO of the company or a newly
hired software development engineer
nobody circumvents the process if you
have a new idea you'll say what why
don't you write a press release and
let's get started from there and again
the key is that it's rooted in a
customer problem or opportunity and a
real benefit yeah we've seen a company
like amazonian how do they foster and
harness innovation yeah what well I I
think what's really interesting is goes
back to what we call mechanisms some
people call them processes but there are
these ways that we reinforce the the
aspects of our culture and learning that
we think are important and so the the
working backwards process is a key one
which is we're always our roadmaps 95
percent of what we build for customers
come straight from the customer what
they're telling us and we we learned
that from meeting with customers I
personally meet with about a hundred and
fifty customers a year one-on-one and
and that to us even though we're data
driven and use data to make a lot of our
decisions customer anecdotes and what
they're telling us is really the the key
driver and what we want to do
you
